tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: General Information:
tn.text: This psalm is a song of praise.

tn.ref: For the chief musician
tn.text: "This is for the director of music to use in worship"

tn.ref: Make a joyful noise to God, all the earth
tn.text: A "joyful noise to God" represents singing and shouting praises to God.  AT: "Let all the earth sing and shout joyfully to God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: all the earth
tn.text: This refers to all the people who live on the earth. AT: "everyone on earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Sing out the glory of his name; make his praise glorious
tn.text: These phrases have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize how wonderful God is. AT: "Sing about how wonderful God's name is; sing wonderful praise about how great God is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the glory of his name
tn.text: God's name here represents God himself. AT: "his glory" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: How terrifying are your deeds
tn.text: The works of God cause us to be in awe and terrified because we know he is powerful and holy.

tn.ref: By the greatness of your power
tn.text: "Because you have great power"

tn.ref: All the earth will worship you
tn.text: This refers to all of the people who live on the earth. AT: "All the people on earth will worship you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: they will sing to your name
tn.text: Here "your name" refers to God himself. AT: "they will praise and honor you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: he ... his ... him
tn.text: Here all these words refer to God.

tn.ref: fearsome
tn.text: "awesome"

tn.ref: the sons of mankind
tn.text: "humanity"

tn.ref: He turned the sea into dry land; they went through the river on foot
tn.text: This refers to the crossing of the Red Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit|Assumed Knowledge and Implicit Information]])

tn.ref: they went
tn.text: The word "they" refers to God's people, the Israelites.

tn.ref: we rejoiced
tn.text: The word "we" refers to the Israelites, their ancestors, David, and the people he is speaking to. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive|Inclusive "We"]])

tn.ref: his eyes observe
tn.text: The phrase "his eyes" refers to God himself. AT: "he sees" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche|Synecdoche]])

tn.ref: let not the rebellious exalt themselves
tn.text: "let not the rebellious people exalt themselves" or "let not the rebellious people be proud"

tn.ref: Give blessing to God ... let the sound of his praise be heard
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings. The idea is repeated to emphasize the importance of praising God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: our
tn.text: In these verses the word "our" includes David and the people he is speaking to. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

tn.ref: he does not permit our feet to slip
tn.text: The writer speaks of God's protection as preventing his people from slipping as they walk or falling off a cliff. AT:"he has not allowed us to fall into disaster" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You brought us into a net
tn.text: The writer speaks of God's punishment as if God had captured his people in a net. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a net
tn.text: a trap for a bird or an animal

tn.ref: you laid a severe burden on our waists
tn.text: The writer speaks of what the people have endured as having to carry heavy loads on their backs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: You made people ride over our heads
tn.text: This is a picture of being horribly defeated in battle. AT: "It is as if our enemies defeated us in battle and then drove their chariots over our fallen bodies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: went through fire and water
tn.text: God tested them with natural disasters like fires and floods. AT: "we suffered like people who suffer from fires and floods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: spacious place
tn.text: The writer speaks of the blessings that the people of Israel now have as if they had been brought into a wide open space where they are safe. AT: "open place where we are safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: which my lips promised and my mouth spoke
tn.text: Here "lips" and "mouth" refer to the words of promise that were spoken. AT: "which I promised" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: aroma of rams
tn.text: "smell of the smoke of sacrificed rams"

tn.ref: I will declare what he has done for my soul
tn.text: The word "soul" represents the whole person. AT: "I will tell you what he has done for me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I cried to him with my mouth
tn.text: The word "mouth" represents the whole person who cries out to God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: he was praised with my tongue
tn.text: Here "tongue" represents words or speech. This can be stated in active form. AT: "I praised him with my tongue" or "I praised him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: seen sin
tn.text: "loved sin" or "held iniquity"

tn.ref: would not have listened to me
tn.text: Here "would not have listened" implies that God would not have answered his prayer. This can be made clear in the translation. AT: "would not have heard me call out to him" or "he would not have answered my prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: But God has truly heard; he has paid attention
tn.text: These two clauses have similar meanings and are used together to emphasize that God has heard his prayer. AT: "But God has truly heard my prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: the voice of my prayer
tn.text: Here the author's prayer is given the personal quality of having a voice. AT: "my prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: or his covenant faithfulness from me
tn.text: The implied words can be added to the translation. AT: "or turned his covenant faithfulness away from me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
